## Introduction

> This section of my portfolio demonstrates my capabilities in statistical modeling (Monte Carlo Simulations) using functional programming. Simulations are useful when there is insufficient data for a specific scenario, but you have parameters and an idea of how the variables might behave. These inferences can be used to model your data, providing a broader understanding of how to approach and better comprehend its essence.
>
> When I learned about regression models, my teacher taught us by using simulation modeling. He created a game for us to get hands on experience in simulations.
> We had to design a simulated data set with specific parameters chosen by ourselves to create any laws/models that we wanted. Then put us to compete against each other and see who could figure out the other student's model by using regression techniques. 
> 
> Here I'll show you one of my models, I did not compete with this model in the Regression Battleship game as I did with my other model shown in my portfolio. However this model was actually more complex to simulate.


```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(pander)
library(tidyverse)
```

```{r}
         base1 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         temple9 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         base2 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         temple10 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==1, 1, 0))

mylm <- lm(y ~ trmp:x1 + 
            temple1 + temple1:x1 +
            temple2 + temple2:x1 +
            temple3 + temple3:x1 +
            temple4 +
            temple5 +
            temple6 + temple6:x1 +
            temple7 + 
            temple8 + 
            temple9 + temple9:x1 +
            temple10 + temple10:x1 +
            hof +
            grass1 +
            grass2 +
            moroni1 + moroni1:I(x1^2) +
            moroni2 + moroni2:I(x1^2) +
            door + door:I(x1^4) +
            base1 + base1:I(x1^4) +
            base2 + base2:I(x1^4) , templelm
            )
```

> <p style="color: #127566; text-align: left;"><strong>**Desmos Model**</strong></p>

Now, to show you how it all started here is the blueprint of my model before I programmed it in R. We started the regression game by designing our model in Desmos as a drawing, each different color would represent a different regression line with change in intercepts and slope based on my programming.

> <p style="color: #127566; text-align: left;"><strong>**Code**</strong></p>

**I purposely made the table below be in a raw-format** so that the output summary shows all details; especially that all terms are significant even at the **.01** level.

<div class="latex-container">

```{r}

n <- 1500
 
x1 <- runif(n,-15,15)

x2 <- sample(c(0,1), n, replace = T)

x7 <- "The House Of The Lord"

x10 <- (x6+1)/(x5+4)

temple <- data.frame(y, x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6, x7 = as.factor(x7), x8 = as.factor(x8), x9 = as.factor(x9), x10 = as.factor(x10)) |> filter(y > .5)

templelm <- temple |> 
  mutate(
    trmp = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple1 = if_else(x2 == 1 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple2 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         door = if_else(x2 == 1 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple3 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple4 = if_else(x2 == 1 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple5 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple6 = if_else(x2 == 1 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         moroni1 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple7 = if_else(x2 == 1 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         grass1 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         temple8 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         grass2 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==0, 1, 0),
         moroni2 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         hof = if_else(x2 == 1 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         base1 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 1 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         temple9 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 0 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         base2 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==0 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==1, 1, 0),
         temple10 = if_else(x2 == 0 & x3 == 0 & x4 ==1 & x5 == 1 & x6 ==1, 1, 0))

mylm <- lm(y ~ trmp:x1 + 
            temple1 + temple1:x1 +
            temple2 + temple2:x1 +
            temple3 + temple3:x1 +
            temple4 +
            temple5 +
            temple6 + temple6:x1 +
            temple7 + 
            temple8 + 
            temple9 + temple9:x1 +
            temple10 + temple10:x1 +
            hof +
            grass1 +
            grass2 +
            moroni1 + moroni1:I(x1^2) +
            moroni2 + moroni2:I(x1^2) +
            door + door:I(x1^4) +
            base1 + base1:I(x1^4) +
            base2 + base2:I(x1^4) , templelm
            )

summary(mylm)
```
